item.title: Anima
item.description:
Once activated, the addon will add the Anima singleton class to your project.

Custom nodes link

Anima provides those two additional nodes:

  • AnimaNode, used to handle the setup of all the animations supported by the addon
  • AnimaTween, is the custom Tween used that allows the magic to happen :)

Syntax link

  • begin(node, animation_name, is_single_shot)
  • begin_single_shot(node, animation_name)

Reference link

begin link

This method is used to programmatically add the AnimaNode to the scene as a child of the specified node one. It will return the AnimaNode added attached to the specified node.

item.title: Anima.Node
item.description:
This class is used to animate a single node.

Syntax link

 Anima.Node(node: Node, delay = null) -> AnimaDeclaration
param type Description
node Node The node to animate
delay float The delay before starting the animation

Example link

 (
 Anima.Node($Label)
 .anima_fade_in()
 .play_with_delay(0.5)
)

item.title: Anima.Nodes
item.description:
The Anima.MultiNode class allows you to animate multiple independent nodes simultaneously. This provides a flexible way to create custom animation groups beyond the built-in Anima.Group and Anima.Grid classes.

Key Distinction:

Unlike Anima.Group and Anima.Grid, which target the children of a node, Anima.MultiNode directly animates the specified nodes themselves. This enables you to define your own “group” of nodes for animation, regardless of their hierarchical relationship.

Syntax link

 Anima.Nodes(node: Array[Node], items_delay: int = 0) -> AnimaDeclaration

item.title: Anima.Grid
item.description:
This class is used to animate all the direct child of the node specified.

Syntax link

 Anima.Grid(grid: Node, grid_size: Vector2, items_delay: float, animation_type: int = GROUP.FROM_TOP, point := 0)
